metadata.case_name: Union of India v. Major Lala, Lt. Col. Khanna and Gupta

facts.text: Two of the appellants, Major Lala and Lt. Col. Khanna are Army officers and the appellant in the 3rd appeal, Gupta, is a businessman of Gauhati.
All three were put up for trial before the Special Judge appointed under the Criminal Law Amendment Act 1952.

Common charge to all three: between June 1962 and January 1963 all of them agreed to commit or cause to be committed offences under section 5(2) of the Prevention of Corruption Act, and of cheating punishable under section 420 of the Indian Penal Code, and these offences having been committed in pursuance of a conspiracy were punishable under section 120B of the Indian Penal Code read with section 5(2) of the Prevention of Corruption Act and section 420 I.P.C.
Mr. Gupta charged under section 420 I.P.C. as well as section 511 read with section 420 I.P.C.
The two Army officers charged with offences under section 420 read with section 5(1)(d) of the Prevention of Corruption Act.
Case filed before the Special Judge on 28-6-1963.

After about 18 out of the 52 witnesses cited by the prosecution had been examined the three respondents filed petitions under section 561A read with section 439 of Code of Criminal Procedure before the High Court of Assam Nagaland on 28-3-68, 1-4-68 and 10-4-68 respectively for quashing the charges.

Learned Single Judge allowed these petitions on 23-5-1969 and quashed the charges and the proceedings before the learned Special Judge on three grounds: 1) officer who investigated the case was not competent to do so; 2) offences non-cognizable and Special Judge could not have taken cognizance without sanction under section 196A CrPC; 3) enormous length of time between 2-2-63 (case registered) and 1-4-68 (some witness examined, last on 15-1-67) entailed undue harassment.

Officer was an Inspector of the Delhi Special Police Establishment. Under section 5A of the Prevention of Corruption Act (pre-1964 amendment), no officer below Deputy Superintendent of Police could investigate without order of Presidency Magistrate or First Class Magistrate. Inspector obtained order of First Class Magistrate of Tezpur.
Order of Tezpur Magistrate dated 4-2-63: 'Paper and F.I.R. seen. Shri H. B. D. Baijal, Inspector is permitted to investigate the case.'
Superintendent of Special Police Establishment order dated 2-2-63 entrusting investigation to Inspector Baijal and directing him to obtain permission from competent Magistrate.
Item 71 of papers given to accused under s.173 CrPC relates to order of sanction dated 4-2-1963 by Tezpur Magistrate.
Sanction under section 6 of Prevention of Corruption Act and section 197 CrPC accorded by Government of India.
Respondents took nearly three years before moving High Court for quashing.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Inspector of Delhi Special Police Establishment was competent to investigate, having obtained order only from Tezpur Magistrate when offences alleged at Tezpur and Gauhati.
Whether offences under ss.161,165,165A IPC and s.5(2) Prevention of Corruption Act are cognizable or non-cognizable, and whether sanction under s.196A CrPC is necessary.
Whether enormous delay from 2-2-63 to 1-4-68 causes undue harassment warranting quashing of proceedings.
Whether Gupta (businessman) can be tried along with Army officers before Special Judge.

petitioner_arguments.text: Investigating Inspector had order from Tezpur First Class Magistrate, which is sufficient as offence parts occurred there; no need for order from every jurisdiction.
Offences under ss.161,165,165A IPC and s.5 PC Act are cognizable per Schedule II CrPC; s.5A only limits who can investigate/arrest, does not change cognizability.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: CrPC ss.4(1)(f), Schedule II, s.5; PC Act s.5(2)

petitioner_arguments.text: Delay partly due to respondents who moved High Court after 3 years; no need for s.196A sanction.
Gupta can be jointly tried under Criminal Law Amendment Act s.7(3) and CrPC ss.235,239 as part of same transaction/conspiracy.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Criminal Law Amendment Act 1952 ss.6,7(3); CrPC ss.235,239

respondent_arguments.text: Investigator needed orders from both Tezpur and Gauhati Magistrates as offences at both places.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: PC Act s.5A; Chinnappa v. State of Mysore; Chatterjee v. Delhi Special Police Establishment

respondent_arguments.text: Offences non-cognizable due to s.5A restrictions on arrest/investigation by lower officers, requiring s.196A sanction.
Enormous delay from 2-2-63 to 1-4-68 causes harassment, abuse of process.
Gupta cannot be tried with Army officers.

court_reasoning.text: Tezpur Magistrate order sufficient as he had territorial jurisdiction over part of offence; no need for orders from every jurisdiction where conspiracy parts occurred.
court_reasoning.key_observation: All that is necessary is that the Magistrate who makes the order under section 5A should have territorial jurisdiction over the place where any part of the ingredients of the offence took place.

court_reasoning.text: High Court Judge should have verified genuineness of Tezpur order thoroughly; records confirm it was genuine and produced earlier.
court_reasoning.key_observation: There is no doubt at all that Inspector Baijal had been authorized to investigate into this case.

court_reasoning.text: Offences are cognizable per CrPC Schedule II and s.4(1)(f); s.5A PC Act only limits competent officers, does not alter cognizability; no s.196A sanction needed.
court_reasoning.key_observation: The mere fact that under the Prevention of Corruption Act certain restrictions are placed as to the officers who are competent to investigate into offences mentioned in section 5A would not make those offences any the less cognizable offences.

court_reasoning.text: Delay issue does not arise as no s.196A needed; respondents responsible for part of delay.
court_reasoning.key_observation: The respondents took nearly three years before they moved the High Court for quashing the charges and are, thus, to a considerable extent responsible for the delay.

court_reasoning.text: Gupta can be tried jointly as conspiracy part of same transaction; Special Judge jurisdiction under CLAA s.7(3) and CrPC ss.235,239.
court_reasoning.key_observation: There is no objection to Mr. Gupta being tried along with the two Army officers.

holdings.text: Investigating Inspector competent with Tezpur Magistrate order.
Offences under ss.161,165,165A IPC and s.5 PC Act are cognizable; no s.196A sanction required.
Joint trial of all accused permissible.

precedents_cited.relevance: Any First Class Magistrate in district can issue s.5A order; not authority for needing orders from every jurisdiction.

precedents_cited.case_name: Chatterjee v. Delhi Special Police Establishment
precedents_cited.relevance: Upheld in Union of India v. B.N. Ananthpadmanabhaiah; Delhi Magistrate order invalid for Assam offences, but not requiring multiple local orders.

precedents_cited.case_name: Union of India v. B.N. Ananthpadmanabhaiah
precedents_cited.relevance: Delhi Magistrate sanction invalid for Assam offences.

precedents_cited.case_name: H.N. Rishbud v. State of Delhi
precedents_cited.relevance: No support for distinction based on investigation under s.156 CrPC vs s.5A PC Act.

precedents_cited.case_name: G.K. Apte v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Erroneous view that s.5A investigation makes offence non-cognizable needing s.196A.
s.5A restrictions do not make offence non-cognizable.
Offence u/s 165A IPC cognizable despite s.5A.
s.161 IPC cognizable unaffected by PC Act ss.3,5A.

precedents_cited.case_name: Union of India v. Mahesh Chandra
precedents_cited.relevance: Emphasized s.5A provision but not changing cognizability.
s.5A special provision; offences remain cognizable.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Andhra Pradesh v. Kandimalla Subbiah
precedents_cited.relevance: Joint trial permissible under CrPC s.239 for conspiracy/same transaction; Special Judge jurisdiction u/s.7(3) CLAA.

statutes_cited.name: Prevention of Corruption Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Offences under s.5(2); s.5A limits investigating officers but offences cognizable; s.6 sanction given.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898
statutes_cited.relevance: Cognizability defined s.4(1)(f), Schedule II lists offences cognizable; s.196A for non-cognizable not needed; joint trial ss.235,239; quashing petitions s.561A r/w 439.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Conspiracy s.120B r/w PC Act and s.420; substantive offences ss.161 etc. cognizable.

statutes_cited.name: Criminal Law Amendment Act, 1952
statutes_cited.relevance: Special Judge jurisdiction over conspiracy/abetment/attempt of specified offences and other offences in same trial.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed the appeals by certificate, set aside the High Court order quashing the charges and proceedings before the Special Judge, holding the investigation valid, offences cognizable without need for s.196A sanction, no quashing on delay grounds, and joint trial permissible. Proceedings restored without commenting on merits.
outcome.relief_granted: Charges and proceedings before Special Judge restored.

key_quotes.text: All that is necessary is that the Magistrate who makes the order under section 5A should have territorial jurisdiction over the place where any part of the ingredients of the offence took place.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects need for multiple magistrate orders for conspiracy spanning jurisdictions.

key_quotes.text: The mere fact that under the Prevention of Corruption Act certain restrictions are placed as to the officers who are competent to investigate into offences mentioned in section 5A would not make those offences any the less cognizable offences.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on cognizability unaffected by s.5A.

key_quotes.text: How can there be a case which is neither cognizable nor non-cognizable?
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects illogical distinction based on investigating officer rank.
